content.raw:
(Note none of this is written in stone, this is just my current suggestion)

> Is each secondary runner runner associated with a level in the world (as opposed to a performer)?

When multiple performers are in the same level, they're necessarily in the same runner.

An alternative we discussed was to only move performers to the same runner when they're about to collide, which is essentially like smaller levels that move around each performer (the performer's window). My personal feeling is that having one extra layer beyond levels (the windows) will add much complexity with little gain. In any case we will have situations when many performers must be in the same runner.

I think there can be multiple levels simulated in the same runner, such as in the single performer example below. I think we could make this configurable, but I'm not clear on what the parameters could be.

So in the situation when all robots start in the same level, the simulation starts slow, with a single runner simulating them all. Then as robots move to different levels, new runners are spun up and levels are spread across them.
